title: Theodorus Marinus Roest van Limburg
text:
Baron Theodorus Marinus Roest van Limburg or de Limbourg (8 July 1806, <a href="Rotterdam">Rotterdam</a> – 3 March 1887, <a href="Florence">Florence</a>) was a Dutch journalist, diplomat, and politician.
Early life.
He studied law in <a href="Li%C3%A8ge">Liège</a>, <a href="Ghent">Ghent</a> and <a href="Leiden">Leiden</a> (1827-1831).
Career.
He worked at the Departments of Colonies and Foreign Affairs. From 1837 till 1841 he served as editor of the liberal newspaper "<a href="Arnhem">Arnhem</a>sche Courant". His diplomatic career started in 1842, when he was named secretary of the Dutch <a href="Legation">Legation</a> in <a href="Vienna">Vienna</a>. From 1851-1856 he served as <a href="Charg%C3%A9%20d%E2%80%99affaires">Chargé d’affaires</a> in <a href="Lisbon">Lisbon</a> and he became <a href="Envoy%20%28title%29">Envoy</a> in <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington</a>, serving from 1856 until 1868.
Roest van Limburg became <a href="List%20of%20Ministers%20of%20Foreign%20Affairs%20of%20the%20Netherlands">Minister of Foreign Affairs</a> in 1868. His tenure as Foreign Minister was marked by the <a href="Franco-German%20War">Franco-German War</a> from 1870 to 1871 in the <a href="Liberalism%20in%20the%20Netherlands">liberal</a> cabinet of <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20the%20Netherlands">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Pieter%20Philip%20van%20Bosse">Pieter Philip van Bosse</a>. There was little confidence in him in the <a href="House%20of%20Representatives%20%28Netherlands%29">House of Representatives</a> which led to his resignation, which was honorably granted. After his resignation he lived abroad.
Personal life.
On 23 August 1858, Roest van Limburg was married to the American Isabella "Belle" Cass (1805-1879) in <a href="Stonington%2C%20Michigan">Stonington</a>, <a href="Michigan">Michigan</a>. Isabella was the daughter of Elizabeth (<a href="n%C3%A9e">née</a> Spencer) Cass and <a href="Lewis%20Cass">Lewis Cass</a>, who served as governor of the <a href="Michigan%20Territory">Michigan Territory</a>, <a href="U.S.%20Secretary%20of%20War">U.S. Secretary of War</a>, <a href="U.S.%20Secretary%20of%20State">U.S. Secretary of State</a>, <a href="U.S.%20Ambassador%20to%20France">U.S. Ambassador to France</a>, and a <a href="United%20States%20Senate">U.S. Senator</a>.
He died on 3 March 1887 in <a href="Florence">Florence</a>.
